testTitle: Life in the UK Test - Post-War Britain & Social Change
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering the period from 1950s to 1980s, including social changes, immigration, cultural developments, politics, and economic transformations in modern Britain.

questions.stem: Elizabeth II became queen in which year?
questions.explanation: Elizabeth II became queen in 1952 following the death of her father, King George VI. Her coronation was in 1953.

questions.stem: The coronation of Elizabeth II was televised.
questions.explanation: True. Elizabeth II's coronation in 1953 was the first major royal event to be televised, watched by millions worldwide.

questions.stem: Which ship brought the first large group of Caribbean immigrants to Britain?
questions.explanation: The Empire Windrush brought 492 Caribbean passengers to Britain in 1948, marking the beginning of large-scale Caribbean immigration.

questions.stem: The Windrush generation settled mainly in which areas?
questions.explanation: Caribbean immigrants typically settled in London, Birmingham, Manchester, and other industrial cities where work was available.

questions.stem: The 1960s were known as the 'Swinging Sixties'.
questions.explanation: True. The 1960s were called the 'Swinging Sixties' due to cultural revolution, fashion, music, and social liberation.

questions.stem: Which band became internationally famous in the 1960s?
questions.explanation: The Beatles, Rolling Stones, and The Who all became famous in the 1960s. Oasis came much later in the 1990s.

questions.stem: Mary Quant is famous for designing what?
questions.explanation: Mary Quant is credited with popularizing the mini skirt in the 1960s, revolutionizing women's fashion.

questions.stem: Comprehensive schools were introduced to replace the 11-plus system.
questions.explanation: True. Comprehensive schools were introduced in the 1960s and 1970s to provide equal education opportunities for all children.

questions.stem: What was the purpose of comprehensive schools?

options.label: To prepare students for university only

questions.explanation: Comprehensive schools aimed to provide equal opportunities, end 11+ selection, and educate children of all abilities together.

questions.stem: The Open University was founded in which decade?
questions.explanation: The Open University was founded in 1969 to provide university education through distance learning and television.

questions.stem: Capital punishment was abolished in Britain in the 1960s.
questions.explanation: True. Capital punishment was suspended in 1965 and formally abolished in 1969, representing a major social reform.

questions.stem: Homosexuality was decriminalized in England and Wales in 1967.
questions.explanation: True. The Sexual Offences Act 1967 decriminalized homosexuality between consenting adults in private in England and Wales.

questions.stem: Who was the first female Prime Minister of the UK?
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher became the first female Prime Minister in 1979, serving until 1990.

questions.stem: The three-day week occurred in which decade?
questions.explanation: The three-day week occurred in 1974 during Edward Heath's government due to industrial disputes and power shortages.

questions.stem: Britain joined the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1973.
questions.explanation: True. Britain joined the EEC in 1973 under Edward Heath's Conservative government, after previous applications were rejected.

questions.stem: What were the main issues of the 1970s?
questions.explanation: The 1970s were marked by high inflation, frequent strikes, and power shortages. There was no World War III.

questions.stem: The Winter of Discontent occurred in 1978-79.
questions.explanation: True. The Winter of Discontent (1978-79) saw widespread strikes by public sector workers, helping to bring down Callaghan's government.

questions.stem: Which industries were privatized in the 1980s?
questions.explanation: Thatcher privatized many industries including BT, gas, and water companies. The NHS remained public.

questions.stem: The Falklands War occurred in 1982.
questions.explanation: True. The Falklands War was fought between Britain and Argentina in 1982, lasting 74 days.

questions.stem: Immigration from which regions increased in the 1960s-70s?
questions.explanation: Immigration increased from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and East Africa (including Ugandan Asians expelled in 1972).

questions.stem: The Race Relations Act was passed to prevent discrimination.
questions.explanation: True. Race Relations Acts (1965, 1968, 1976) were passed to prevent racial discrimination and promote equality.

questions.stem: Which festivals celebrated diversity in British culture?
questions.explanation: Notting Hill Carnival, started in the 1960s, celebrates Caribbean culture and became Europe's largest street festival.

questions.stem: Decimal currency was introduced in 1971.
questions.explanation: True. Decimal Day (15 February 1971) introduced new currency with 100 new pence to the pound, replacing the old £sd system.

questions.stem: What replaced the old currency system in 1971?
questions.explanation: The decimal system introduced 100 new pence to the pound, replacing the old system of 240 old pence (20 shillings) to the pound.
